Misconduct charges continue
By MARC DUVOISIN
Amid new allegations of misconduct from present and former
members of the swim team, Hopkins' Swim Coach Frank Comfort
continued yesterday to deny that
he has exerted influence in the
offices of Admissions and Financial Aid beyond making rudimentary recommendations
through Athletic Director Bob
Scott.
The new charges—along with
information released to the
News-Letter this week—suggest
that Comfort has had more extensive and more influential communication with Admissions and
Financial Aid than he has acknowledged to date.
In interviews conducted this
week, several students, all of
whom requested anonymity, concurred that Comfort has sent letters to the Admissions Office on
behalf of swimming prospects he
would like to see admitted, and
that he maintains a closer rapport
with both the Admissions and
Financial Aid offices than he has
admitted.
Comfort, however, asserted
that he has no communication
with either Financial Aid or Admissions beyond a list of athletes
he is "interested in" which is forwarded to these offices through
Scott.
"I send Admissions the names
of students I'm interested in
through Bob Scott's office," he
said. "Then it's up to them what
they're going to do."
Comfort stated that he never
actually has any official contact
at all with Admissions or Financial Aid officials. "In theory, I
don't speak to them at all; of
course, if Bob Scott is ill and
something comes up, then I do."
He said that charges that he
had sent letters to Admissions are
"just not true."
"I have never sent any letter to
the Admissions people," he said,
" and I would never do such a
thing."
The January 28 copy of the
"Swimming Newsletter," which
is written and sent to high school
swimmers by Comfort, reads in
part: "As your swimming times
and or test scores continue to improve, please let me know, for
this helps in my communication
with the Admissions Office."
Comfort denied that the pas-

sage is evidence of any continued
communication with Admissions,
asserting that new knowledge
which he acquires about prospects' test scores or swimming
times is used only to determine
priorities on the list which he
sends to Admissions.
"It's helpful for me to know
how these high school swimmers
are improving, so I can make my
own decision about who I'm
interested in," he explained.
Scott defended Comfort in
light of the new charges, emphasizing that recommendations
made through his office are only
a supporting criterion secondary
to "whether or not a student is
able to do the work at Hopkins."
"I'm the liaison person
between the coaches and the Admissions Office," he explained.
"We want the contact to be primarily through one person so
that we don't have a dozen
people making phone calls—one
person doing it is the easiest
way."
He said that such communication with Admissions takes

place primarily in late February
and early March, when "the
applications are in and we've set
up our priorities."

By BOB BUCHANAN
Hopkins' annual Rush will begin tonight with a solicitation of
freshmen in the dormitory residneces. The four fraternities south
of the campus—Alpha Tau
Omega, Sigma Phi Epsilon,
Kappa Alpha, and Sigma Nu—will
hold their first parties Friday
night. Northern fraternities Phi
Gamma Delta, Tau Epsilon Phi,
Phi Kapp Si, Delta Phi, and Delta
Upsilon will hold their initial
parties the following night.
Beta Theta Pi, the fraternity
which recently relinquished the
mortgage of its previous residence on Canterbury Road to Phi
Kapp Si, will conduct its rush
parties in the private residences
of some of its members in
Belvedere, Maryland.
Rush will take on added significance this year for Hopkins'ten
fraternities, according to Rick
Hill, President of the Hopkins
Council for InterFraternity Affairs. "The life of some of the
smaller, less established fraternities will depend on rush."

George Owen

According to Hill, last year's
rush proved highly successful to
Hopkins fraternities. "It was the
best in several years. Over 100
men eventually pledged."
However, Hill contended that
the completion of the Hopkins
Union Rathskellar may present
some problems this year for the
less established fraternities. "This
year is critical in that it will determine what role the Rathskellar
will play in fraternity life."
Rathskellar
The Rathskellar has provided a
great deal in the way of social activity for members of the Hopkins community, Hill said.
Though the main role of fraternities at Hopkins is to improve
the social life of their members,
Hill said that "other intangibles"
form much ofthe value of fraternity life.
Concerning the effect the
Rathskellar will ultimately have
on the success of this year's rush,
Hill commented,"I think the
Rathskellar was a novelty. Its effect will wear off and people will

turn back to fraternities."
Attendance at the open parties
given by fraternities for members
of the Hopkins community and
surrounding women's colleges has
dipped dramatically this year.
The completion of the Rathskellar, is the main cause of this
partial demise, according to Hill.
However, fraternities are not
financially dependent on revenues received from admission proceeds to these parties. Steve
Ponchak, member of Tau Epsilon
Phi, stated, "Fraternities are not
being hurt by a lack of attendance at these parties."
"We get very little revenue
from this source. Most of the revenues come from members'
dues."

Among other things, the process of faculty hiring underscores the pretense that goes into the growth and maintenance of the reputation of an academic institution. If it is true

baseball star who is a free agent, and who can negotiate a
contract with any team he likes when he is satisfied with the
compensation offered. He can hold out for a greater salary,
better working conditions, and of course fringe benefits. Just

outpricing one another for faculty.

faculty membership in a state of flux. Just as has happened in

members have no sense of loyalty to their institution. It is

Some inner cities have special schools. For
little boys who don't talk.
Not mute little boys. But children so withdrawn
so afraid of failure, they cannot make the slightest
attempt to do anything at which they might fail.
Some don't talk. Some don't listen. Most don't
behave. And all of them don't learn.
One day someone asked us to help.
Kodak responded by working with the teachers.
Showed them how,through the language of pictures,
the children could communicate as they never could
before. And the teachers sent the kids out to take
pictures with their cameras.
And then the miracle. Little boys who had never
said anything, looked at the pictures and began to
talk. They said "This is my house." "This is my dog."
"This is where I like to hide." They began to explain,

to describe, to communicate. And once the channels of communication had been opened, they
began to learn.
What does Kodak stand to gain from this? Well,
we're showing how our products can help a teacher
—and maybe creating a whole new market. And
we're also cultivating young customers who will
someday buy their own cameras and film. But more
than that, we're cultivating alert, educated citizens.
Who will someday be responsible for our society.
After all, our business depends on society. So
we care what happens to it.
